item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Yet the investigation reported shows that a huge fraction of Masliah's papers contain image manipulations. So far 1 in 6 of his papers spanning 27 years have been flagged, and many have not yet been checked.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: His lab has a systemic problem and it undermines confidence in all his work: people don't cheat if it's unnecessary. For the innocent in the audience, to prove me wrong, you will need to check the original data. Good luck with that under NIH's risible 4-year retention rule!

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: First big question. How did nobody in a lab operating in this way for 26 years and producing 800 papers not raise an alert? If your data are altered, you notice. Were junior members systematically intimidated? Throughout their subsequent careers?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: The so far uniformly positive views of his personality do not suggest a particularly toxic lab culture, but Masliah's uniquely powerful position may have enabled effective silencing. We'll probably soon find out if earlier alerts were buried.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Alternatively, did those junior members consider that behaviour normal? That's a scary thought to which I'll return.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Second big question. This lab churned out untrustworthy research. Yet according to publication and citation data, as well as his appointment, the field basically elected him leader.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Did nobody in the field notice the work was unreliable? Is it possible that this unreliable work was no worse or maybe still better than most of the rest of the field's production?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Rather than neurodegeneration research progressively accumulating carefully validated research, this gives the impression of a field barely treading water in a swamp of untrustworthy results.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: In this context, James Heather's recent estimate that 1/7 papers contains falsified or fabricated results suddenly seems very plausible. https://osf.io/s4gce

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: James also asked whether cheats might not be more prolific than honest researchers. And of course, like here, they are. Almost by definition, people cheat for speed.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Third big question. What are NIH going to do about their huge procedural weaknesses this affair reveals?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: For NIH-funded researchers, the organisation usually seems quite unintersted in integrity issues, beyond emitting incantations about "taking integrity issues very seriously" after every new scandal.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Here, somewhat surprisingly, NIH had carried out some sort of investigation, presumably following initial posts on PubPeer. Perhaps the in-house employment and high-ranking position of Masliah caught their attention and obliged them to do something.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Nevertheless, a combination of PubPeer, an alert Charles Piller and a couple of volunteer analysts ran rings and looped loops around the NIH investigation, which only looked at 2 papers. Official investigations are crap, again.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Reading between the lines, it seems that NIH are scrambling to adjust to the new information they failed to investigate and were not planning a severe response, since Masliah was still representing the organisation this week. This remains to be clarified.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: The levels of wasted human and financial resources, the potential corruption of science and its administration, are significant. Masliah operated with impunity. NIH procedures are totally ineffective at detecting or deterring career-long, industrial-scale cheating.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: In fact, Convince me that NIH procedures don't in practice facilitate and encourage such cheating. After all, they hired Masliah.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Fourth big question. Conflicts of interest. I assume (but don't know) that Masliah wound up his lab upon taking the NIA job. But, without assuming any specific transactions, it seems likely that Masliah's position might have influenced (negatively) desire to report his misconduct.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Similarly, the industry pursuit of multiple therapeutic strategies based upon his work could well have been influenced (positively) by his position. Did he retain a direct financial interest in these? Is this a CoI to be managed? Is it?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Fifth big question. When will the clinical trials unethically based upon unreliable work be halted?
